fishFacts.fact: Blue whales are the largest animals on Earth, growing up to 100 feet long and weighing as much as 200 tons. They are filter feeders that can consume up to 4 tons of krill per day.
A smasher mantis shrimp punch has the same acceleration as a 22-caliber bullet, delivering a blow of 15,000 newtons, a force equal to more than 2,500 times its weight.

The red-lipped batfish is one of about 60 species of batfish that have modified pectoral and pelvic fins that resemble legs. Although they're capable of swimming, you're likely to find them walking on the sea floor by alternating their limb-like fins

Clown fish can change sex mid-way through their lives! Here's a diagram of how the sex change works. This means Finding Nemo isn't super accurate, because technically Marlin should become a gal once Nemo's mama got eaten by that shark :O
To prevent floating off into the ether and losing each other while they nap, sea otters will sometimes hold hands when they sleep.
After being named the world/’s ugliest animal in 2013, this hideous fish soared to fame—with memes, songs, soft toys, and even TV characters created in its honor.
Dolphins are v smart, so sometimes they use tools! This dolphin is using a sponge to protect its little nose while hunting for fish amidst sharp coral.

Atlantic horseshoe crabs are ancient arthropods that have been around for more than 450 million years. They are important to the medical industry because their blue blood contains a clotting agent that is used to test for bacterial contamination in medical equipment

Some species of anglerfish, the deep-sea predator that uses a luminous lure to attract prey, have a bizarre way of reproducing: they fuse with their mates. We now know how the fish can fuse tissues without triggering a potent immune response

Ice fish are the only vertebrates that lack functional hemoglobin genes. This means their bodies do not produce the red blood cells that carry oxygen in the blood of all other vertebrates. As a result, their blood is a ghostly white color.
The fangtooth is a deep-sea fish that lives at depths of up to 16,000 feet. It has the largest teeth of any fish relative to its body size.
The frilled shark is a primitive species of shark that has remained virtually unchanged for millions of years. It has a unique frilled appearance and can swim backwards.
Sharks are considered a cartilaginous fish, because they don't have bones -- their skeletons are purely made out of cartilage, allowing them to move more quickly through the water.

Greenland sharks are one of the largest fish in the Arctic, with some individuals growing up to 21 feet long. They are the longest-lived vertebrate species on Earth, with a lifespan of up to 400 years.
The viperfish is a deep-sea fish that lives at depths of up to 13,000 feet. It has long, needle-like teeth and a bioluminescent lure that it uses to attract prey.

oceanFacts.fact: The ocean is home to 94% of all life on earth.
The ocean provides more than half of the oxygen we breathe.
The ocean acts as a global climate control system. It regulates the concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere by absorbing, storing, and releasing the greenhouse gas.
There are five major garbage patches in the world. The largest, the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is located between Hawaii and California.
The longest mountain range on Earth is the Mid-Oceanic Ridge, and it's underwater!
One iceberg could supply a million people with drinking water for 5 years.
If all the ice melted, the sea level would rise 26 stories!
